text: Once more, how would you say to pay?
Payee.
Now, if you want to give an order, an instruction in French, you will simply say...
Payee.
Payee.
So you can see that when you want to say to someone pay, as in pay for the meal,
it simply sounds exactly the same as toupee.
Except again, instead of being spelt with an R at the end, as toupee would be,
it's spelt with a Z at the end.
To keep in French is to guard.
How do you think you'd say that in French, to guard?
Gardee.
How would you give it as an instruction and simply say keep?
Gardee.
Gardee.
The change in French sounds very similar, very, very similar to saying the money in English.
And so the word the change in French is...
La money.
La money.
So how do you think you'd say keep the change?
Gardee la money.
Again, what was I want?
Je veux.
How do you think you'd say I want it?
Je le veux.
As you can see, and as we practiced earlier, the le always likes to come first.
So, to understand.
What was to understand?
Comprendre.
To understand it.
Le comprendre.
I want to understand it.
Je veux le comprendre.
So, in English, when you say I want to understand it, the it comes after.
In French, it simply comes before.
If you want to say I want it, again, in English, the it comes after the want, but in French,
it comes before.
So again, I want it.
Je le veux.
To say a bottle of white wine, this is quite common even in English.
A lot of people know what white wine is in French, perhaps because it's written on wine bottles,
or perhaps because people tend to drink a lot of it.
To say a bottle of white wine in French, you will say...
Une bouteille de vin blanc.
Une bouteille de vin blanc.
How would you say I want a bottle of white wine?
Je veux une bouteille de vin blanc.
A bottle of red wine will be...
Une bouteille de vin rouge.
Une bouteille de vin rouge.
You may be familiar with the word for red in French, rouge, because it's in English.
If you're familiar with the stories of the moulin rouge, literally the windmill red, you'll
know that word already.
So, one more time.
A bottle of red wine.
Une bouteille de vin rouge.
So again, how would you say I want a bottle of white wine, but he wants a bottle of red wine?
A sandwich in French is...
Un sandwich.
Un sandwich.
Un sandwich.
Un sandwich.
Un sandwich.
Un sandwich.
How would you say he wants a bottle of red wine and a sandwich?
Un sandwich.
Il veut une bouteille de vin rouge et un sandwich.
But she wants a bottle of white wine and the dish of the day, or as we still even say in English,
le plat du jour.
Again, you may be familiar with the French use of the dish of the day, because it is used
to some degree in English now as well.
Now, of course, you might not always want to have an entire bottle of white wine by yourself.
And in French, you can simply ask for a white wine.
So how would you say that?
I want a white wine.
Je veux un vin blanc.
And let's try she wants a white wine and the dish of the day, the plat du jour.
She wants a white wine and the dish of the day.
She wants a white wine and the dish of the day.
And let's try she wants a white wine.
And let's try she wants a white wine.
And let's try she wants a white wine.
And let's try she wants a white wine.
And let's try she wants a white wine.
And let's try she wants a white wine.
And let's try she wants a white wine.
And let's try she wants a white wine.
